description: The mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) pathway is a master regulator of cell growth, integrating signals from nutrients (especially amino acids), growth factors (IGF-1, insulin), and energy status (ATP levels). mTOR exists in two complexes: mTORC1 (promotes anabolism, inhibits autophagy) and mTORC2 (regulates metabolism and survival). This pathway is central to aging biology and is a key target for longevity interventions.

crosstalk.mechanism: mTORC1 phosphorylates ULK1 at Ser757, preventing AMPK-mediated ULK1 activation and autophagy initiation. mTOR inhibition relieves this block, activating autophagy.
Reciprocal inhibition: AMPK inhibits mTORC1 via TSC2 and Raptor phosphorylation; mTORC1 activity generally indicates low AMPK activity due to opposing energy states.
Complex relationship: mTORC1 can support mitochondrial biogenesis via 4E-BP1/PGC-1alpha interactions, but chronic overactivation impairs mitophagy. mTOR inhibition enhances mitophagy.
Chronic mTORC1 activation promotes cellular senescence; mTOR inhibition can reduce senescent cell burden and SASP.
IGF-1 signaling activates PI3K-AKT, which activates mTORC1. mTOR is downstream of IGF-1 signaling.

interventions_targeting.specificity: mTORC1 selective at low/pulsed doses; mTORC2 inhibition with prolonged high-dose exposure

interventions_targeting.via: AMPK activation leads to TSC2 activation and mTORC1 inhibition
Amino acid sensing via Sestrin2 and CASTOR1
Reduced amino acids and growth factor signaling
Reduced nutrient and growth factor signaling

biomarker_relevance.notes: IGF-1 activates mTORC1 via PI3K-AKT pathway
Phosphorylated S6K1 is a direct readout of mTORC1 activity

key_evidence.statement: mTOR inhibition with rapamycin extends lifespan in multiple model organisms including yeast, worms, flies, and mice

peer_reviewed_citations.citation: Harrison DE et al. (2009) Rapamycin fed late in life extends lifespan in genetically heterogeneous mice. Nature. 460:392-395

key_evidence.statement: mTORC1 inhibition activates autophagy by relieving ULK1 suppression

peer_reviewed_citations.citation: Kim J et al. (2011) AMPK and mTOR regulate autophagy through direct phosphorylation of Ulk1. Nat Cell Biol. 13:132-141

key_evidence.statement: Weekly pulsed rapamycin dosing preferentially inhibits mTORC1 while allowing mTORC2 function recovery, potentially optimizing the benefit/risk ratio for longevity applications
